{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnic. [CHUNK_12] It also amends and establishes various definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, including establishing heightened penalties under certain circumstances. [CHUNK_12] The measure incorporates fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [CHUNK_13]",
  "appropriations": "Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by deleting the appropriation. [CHUNK_24] The purpose of the measure previously included appropriating funds. [CHUNK_23]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The bill establishes a more robust continuum of enforcement mechanisms to promote compliance with the fireworks control laws. [CHUNK_10] This includes implementing graduated penalties for repeat or felony-level offenses and imposing enhanced penalties for offenses that result in injury or death. [CHUNK_10] The measure also adjudicates fireworks infractions under the same system used for traffic and emergency period infractions, which will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases. [CHUNK_11]",
  "agency_impact": "The fireworks infractions system will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases, while also allowing them to prioritize higher-level cases as appropriate. [CHUNK_11] The system of processing traffic infractions established by chapter 291D is well-suited to certain types of violations of the fireworks control law. [CHUNK_18] Incorporating fireworks infractions into this existing process should allow the judiciary to reserve resources for cases that require more resources. [CHUNK_18]",
  "economic_impact": "The measure establishes a fine of $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for the unlawful purchase or use of consumer fireworks. [CHUNK_0] It also establishes a fine of $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for distributing consumer fireworks outside of permissible time periods. [CHUNK_1] Carriers who violate notification requirements are subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a first offense, a $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a second offense, and a $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a third or subsequent offense. [CHUNK_2] [CHUNK_3] [CHUNK_4]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act amends Chapter 132D, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding seven new sections establishing various criminal offenses and prohibitions related to fireworks. [CHUNK_13] It also amends Chapter 291D, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to incorporate fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [CHUNK_13] The legislature finds that improved enforcement of the fireworks control laws is necessary to protect the community from fire- and explosion-related injuries, respiratory distress caused by air pollution, and recurring trauma due to loud explosions. [CHUNK_9]",
  "revenue_sources": "Fines imposed for violating this chapter will be collected by the court. [CHUNK_12] Of the fines collected, the court shall pay twenty per cent to the State and eighty per cent to the county in which the fine was imposed, which shall be expended by the county for law enforcement purposes. [CHUNK_12] In addition to any monetary assessment, the court shall impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction, which will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [CHUNK_10]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The bill establishes various fines that will generate revenue for the State and counties. [CHUNK_12] A violation for purchasing or possessing consumer fireworks without a permit is subject to a $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [CHUNK_0] Illegal distribution of consumer fireworks is subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [CHUNK_1] Carriers failing to meet shipping requirements face fines starting at $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for a first offense, increasing to $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for a second, and $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for a third or subsequent offense. [CHUNK_2] [CHUNK_3] [CHUNK_4] A fine of $300 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) is established for possessing less than five pounds of certain illegal fireworks. [CHUNK_5] Other violations of the chapter are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_8] [CHUNK_7] Obstructing an inspector is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of no more than $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_9] The court will also impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction where judgment is entered for the State. [CHUNK_10] The collected fines are to be split, with twenty per cent to the State and eighty per cent to the county. [CHUNK_12]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The measure will generate operating revenue through the collection of fines and fees. [CHUNK_12] Of the fines collected, eighty per cent will be paid to the county in which the fine was imposed for law enforcement purposes, and twenty per cent will be paid to the State. [CHUNK_12] Additionally, an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [CHUNK_10]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided documents do not mention any capital expenditures. [CHUNK_0] The measure incorporates fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic infractions, suggesting reliance on current infrastructure. [CHUNK_13]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications after six years will consist of ongoing revenue from the various fines and fees established by the bill. [CHUNK_12] Since the adjudication of fireworks infractions is integrated into the existing system for traffic infractions, it is anticipated that long-term administrative costs will be minimized. [CHUNK_11] The provided legislative documents do not specify any changes to the penalty structure or program after the initial implementation period. [CHUNK_0]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "A significant change from the previous version of the bill is the deletion of the appropriation. [CHUNK_24] The conference committee also amended the measure by providing that the limitation on the number of permits a person may obtain does not apply to permits for aerial devices, articles pyrotechnic, or display fireworks. [CHUNK_24] The new bill specifies the distribution of collected fines, with twenty per cent going to the State and eighty per cent to the county. [CHUNK_12] A new administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction is established to be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [CHUNK_10]"
}
